holidays.name: Skyscraper Day
holidays.description: A day to celebrate the towering giants of architecture that scrape the sky and change city skylines worldwide.
holidays.origin: This day honors the completion of the Home Insurance Building in Chicago on September 3, 1885, often considered the world’s first skyscraper.
holidays.funFact: The first skyscraper was only 10 stories tall, which seems tiny compared to modern behemoths reaching over 100 floors!

holidays.name: Talk Like a Pirate Day
holidays.description: Shiver me timbers! A day dedicated to speaking and acting like a pirate, with plenty of 'Arrr!'
holidays.origin: Created in 1995 by John Baur and Mark Summers, this holiday became an internet sensation and official day observed on September 19. However, some pirate enthusiasts also celebrate an early unofficial version around this date.
holidays.funFact: Massive social media storms and even ship tours have been inspired by this holiday, turning landlubbers into pirates for a day!

holidays.name: National Welsh Rarebit Day
holidays.description: A deliciously cheesy celebration of Welsh Rarebit, the savory melted cheese sauce poured over toasted bread.
holidays.origin: Honoring the beloved British dish, this day encourages everyone to enjoy a hearty slice of golden, cheesy toast.
holidays.funFact: Despite its name, Welsh Rarebit contains no rabbit at all – it’s likely a corruption of 'Welsh Rabbit,' a humorous name for the dish.

holidays.name: Hairball Awareness Day
holidays.description: A quirky awareness day about those pesky hairballs that our feline friends cough up, raising awareness about pet health.
holidays.origin: Started by cat lovers to educate owners on how to prevent and manage hairballs in cats.
holidays.funFact: Some cats can produce hairballs quite frequently — leading to some owners jokingly calling their pets 'fur factories'!
